realWorldExample: When a car suddenly stops, passengers continue to move forward.
explanation: An object in motion (the passenger) stays in motion with the same speed and in the same direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force (the seatbelt or dashboard).
The rocket expels gas downwards (action), and the gas pushes the rocket upwards (reaction). For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

realWorldExample: An apple falling from a tree.
explanation: The Earth exerts a gravitational force on the apple, pulling it downwards.

realWorldExample: Rubbing your hands together to create warmth.
explanation: Friction is a force that opposes motion between surfaces in contact. The work done against friction converts kinetic energy into thermal energy (heat).

realWorldExample: Swinging a bucket of water in a vertical circle without spilling.
explanation: A force directed towards the center of the circular path (provided by the tension in your arm) keeps the bucket (and water) moving in a circle.

realWorldExample: A straw appearing bent in a glass of water.
explanation: Light bends (refracts) when it passes from one medium (air) to another (water) at an angle, changing its speed and direction, creating the illusion.
